prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Remedies for Breach of Confidential Business Information
Legal Basis for a Claim for Damages

para.paratext: As early as 1897 it was acknowledged that:

By the expenditure of labour and money the plaintiffs had acquired this information, and it was in their hands valuable property in this sense—that persons to whom it was not known were willing to pay, and did pay, money to acquire it.[1]

Prior to 1988, many Canadian courts accepted the notion that damages could be awarded to a party whose confidential information had been appropriated by another.[2] However, in R. v. Stewart,[3] Lamer J. for the Supreme Court of Canada held that: “No Canadian court has so far conclusively decided that confidential information is property, with all the civil consequences that such a finding would entail.” He acknowledged that confidential information possesses “many of the characteristics of other forms of property [in that it] can be sold, licensed or bequeathed … it is the product of labour, skill and expenditure, and its unauthorized use would undermine productive efforts which ought to be encouraged”.[4] Lamer J. concluded that:

Confidential information is not of a nature such that it can be converted because if one appropriates confidential information … the alleged owner is not deprived of the use or possession thereof. Since there is no deprivation, there can be no conversion. The only thing that the victim would be deprived of is the confidentiality of the information.[5]

The court in this case refused to acknowledge a property right in confidential information that would protect the rightful owner or user from theft. The court did, however, leave open the possibility that “with time, confidential information will come to be considered as property in the civil law”.[6] To date, no Canadian court has specifically recognized a claim for damages for wrongful appropriation of confidential information based on the law of property.

In AF Industries Ltd. Liability Corp. v. Complete Innovations Inc.,[7] the Court of Appeal rejected the principal submission made by the appellant that the trial judge failed to give effect to her finding that the respondent breached a fiduciary duty owed by it to the appellant. The only breach of fiduciary duty specifically alleged in the statement of defence and repeated in the appellant's factum related to the respondent's alleged use of confidential information to the detriment of the appellant and “to extort monies from the Defendant”. The trial judge found that any alleged use of confidential information did not cause any damages to the appellant. This finding was open to the trial judge. This was not a case like McBride Metal Fabricating Corp. v. H & W Sales Co.,[8] where the trial judge found that had the plaintiff been aware of an apparent breach of fiduciary duty, it would have terminated the agreement. The only breach of fiduciary duty alleged here took place after the parties' agreement had been terminated. It was not open to the appellant to argue for the first time on appeal in oral argument that the breach of fiduciary duty occurred at an earlier time.[9]
Exchange Telegraph Co. v. Central News Ltd., [1897] 2 Ch. 48, at p. 53.

Jiffy Foods Ltd. v. Chomski (1973), 38 D.L.R. (3d) 675, [1973] 3 O.R. 955 (Div. Ct.); Computer Centre Personnel Ltd. v. Lagopoulos (1975), 58 D.L.R. (3d) 352, 8 O.R. (2d) 480 (H.C.J.); Bendix Home Systems Ltd. v. Clayton, [1977] 5 W.W.R. 10, 33 C.P.R. (2d) 230 (B.C.S.C.), wherein the court acknowledged an existing property right but failed to decide the cases on that ground.
AF Industries Ltd. Liability Corp. v. Complete Innovations Inc., 2014 CarswellOnt 749, 2014 ONCA 60.
McBride Metal Fabricating Corp. v. H & W Sales Co., 2002 CarswellOnt 1200, 59 O.R. (3d) 97.
